page.title: List of artificial objects on the Moon

revision.comment: /* Table of objects */ Longjiang-2 impact location added
revision.text:
[[File:Moon map grid showing artificial objects on moon.PNG|thumb|Locations of major spacecraft on the Moon superimposed on data from the ''[[Clementine (spacecraft)|Clementine]]'' mission in [[equirectangular projection]].]] This is a partial list of artificial materials left on the [[Moon]]. The table below does not separately list lesser artificial objects such as [[List of retroreflectors on the Moon|retroreflector]]s, [[Apollo Lunar Surface Experiment Package]]s, tools such as a hammer, or the commemorative, artistic, and personal objects left there by [[Project Apollo|Apollo]] [[astronauts]], such as the [[Lunar Flag Assembly|US flags]], [[Lunar plaque|commemorative plaques]] attached to the ladders of the [[Apollo Lunar Module]]s, the silver [[astronaut pin]] left by [[Alan Bean]] in honor of [[Clifton C. Williams]] whom he replaced, the Bible left by [[David Scott]], the ''[[Fallen Astronaut]]'' statuette and memorial plaque left by the crew of [[Apollo 15]], the [[Apollo 11 goodwill messages]] disc, or the golf balls [[Alan Shepard]] hit during an [[Apollo 14]] moonwalk. The remains of five [[S-IVB]] third stages of [[Saturn V]] rockets from the Apollo program are the heaviest single pieces sent to the lunar surface. Humans have left over {{convert|187,400|kg|lb}} of material on the Moon, and {{convert|838|lb|kg|order=flip}} of [[Moon rock]] was brought back to Earth by Apollo and [[Luna program|Luna]] missions. The only artificial objects on the Moon that are still in use are the retroreflectors for the [[lunar laser ranging experiment]]s left there by the [[Apollo 11]], 14 and 15 astronauts, and by the [[Lunokhod 1]] and [[Lunokhod 2]] missions.[https://books.google.com/books?id=aq_uDo2shjAC&pg=PA300 Slava G. Turyshev – From Quantum to Cosmos: Fundamental Physics Research in Space (2009) – Page 300] Objects at greater than 90 degrees east or west are on the [[Far side (Moon)|far side of the Moon]], including [[Ranger 4]], [[Lunar Orbiter 1]], [[Lunar Orbiter 2]] and [[Lunar Orbiter 3]]. == Legend == {| class="wikitable" style="width:20%; text-align:center;" |- ! style="background:" colspan="2" | Colors |- | style="background:white; width:20px;" | | No data collection |- | style="background:#EFE7B8; width:20px;" | | Transmitted data |- | style="background:#CCFFD9; width:20px;" | | Operational |} ==Table of objects== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! align=left | Artificial object ! align=left | Image ! align=center | Nationality ! align=center | Year ! align=center | Mass (post-mission) | align=left | ? {{cite web|url = https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1969-043A|title = NASA NSSDC Master Catalog - Apollo 10 LM(Snoopy) descent stage|accessdate = 2010-12-24}} |- |-style="background:#EFE7B8" | [[Apollo 11]] LM-5 ''Eagle'' descent stage | [[File:Apollo 11 Lunar Lander - 5927 NASA.jpg|80px|right]] | {{flag|US|1960}} | align=center| 1969 | align=right | 2034 | align=left | Landed | align=left | {{Coord|0.6741|N|23.4730|E|globe:Moon|display=inline}} {{cite web|url = https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1969-059C|title = NASA NSSDC Master Catalog - Apollo 11 LM descent stage|accessdate = 2010-12-25}} |- | [[Luna 15]] |[[File:Luna-16.jpg|80px|right]] | {{flag|USSR}} | align=center| 1969 | align=right | 2718 | align=left | Crashed | align=left | ? {{cite web|url = https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1969-058A|title = NASA NSSDC Master Catalog - Luna 15|accessdate = 2010-12-25}} |- | [[Apollo 11]] LM-5 ''Eagle'' ascent stageThe ascent stage of [[Apollo 10]] was commanded to fire its engine, left lunar orbit and entered solar orbit. The ascent stage of [[Apollo 11]] was left in orbit and thereafter its orbit decayed and it crashed onto the Moon at an unknown location. The [[Apollo 16]] ascent stage failed to crash onto moon when commanded and it decayed from orbit at a later date and also crashed at an unknown location. The ascent stages of the remaining successful missions (Apollo [[Apollo 12|12]], [[Apollo 14|14]], [[Apollo 15|15]], and [[Apollo 17|17]]) were each deliberately crashed onto the Moon. [[Apollo 13]]'s complete [[Apollo Lunar Module]] re-entered Earth's atmosphere after having served as a lifeboat during the aborted mission. |[[File:Apollo 17 LM Ascent Stage.jpg|80px|right]] | {{flag|US|1960}} | align=center| 1969 | align=right | 2184 | align=left | Crashed
(post-mission) | align=left | ? {{cite web|url = https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1969-059C|title = NASA NSSDC Master Catalog - Apollo 11 LM ascent stage|accessdate = 2010-12-25}} |- |-style="background:#EFE7B8" | [[Apollo 12]] LM-6 ''Intrepid'' descent stage |[[File:Bean Descends Intrepid - GPN-2000-001317.jpg|80px|right]] | {{flag|US|1960}} | align=center| 1969 | align=right | 2211 | align=left | Landed | align=left | {{Coord|3.0124|S|23.4216|W|globe:Moon|display=inline}} {{cite web|url = https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1969-099C|title = NASA NSSDC Master Catalog - Apollo 12 LM descent stage|accessdate = 2010-12-25}} |- | [[Apollo 12]] LM-6 ''Intrepid'' ascent stage |[[File:Apollo 17 LM Ascent Stage.jpg|80px|right]] | {{flag|US|1960}} | align=center| 1969 | align=right | 2164 | align=left | Crashed
(post-mission) | align=left | {{Coord|3.94|S|21.20|W|globe:Moon|display=inline}} {{cite web|url = https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1969-099C|title = NASA NSSDC Master Catalog -
